bioghist.p: Father John A. Klekotka (1915-1978) was born in Philadelphia. He was awarded a Bachelor of Science Degree in Electrical Engineering from Villanova College in 1935. He did his theological studies at Augustinian College, Washington, D.C. and was ordained to the priesthood in 1941. The following year he received his Masterâ€™s degree in physics from Catholic University and began to teach at Villanova College. At Villanova Father Klekotka served in many capacities: he was a professor of science, from 1951 to 1956, headed the Electrical Engineering School from 1954 to 1956, was executive coordinator of the Nursing Division from 1954 to 1959, was director of alumni relations from 1957 to 1959, was for a time director of admissions, and from 1959 to 1965 was president of the University. He earlier had also been moderator of the student newspaper, the Villanovan, college chaplain, and for many years, dorm counselor.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Father John A. Klekotka. Correspondence in the collection covers a range of University matters, including Klekotka's appointment as president, the invited commencement speaker Bishop Gerald V. McDevitt, the development of University Plaza, and Klekotka's resignation as president. Additionally the papers includes a set of letters Father Klekotka wrote to Sr. Laurencita during a trip through Asia in 1967. The collection also includes a number of addresses given by Father Klekotka. These addresses include commencement addresses, reports on the Council of Priests of the Archdioces of Philadelphia and the National Federation of Priests' Council, and addresses to Polish cultural societies. Other materials in the collection include: newspaper and Villanova Alumnus magazine articles on Klekotka's presidency of Villanova and his death; a report on the University Plaza project; a Middle States report on the proposed Chemistry Ph.D. program; and legal materials related to conveyance of land (1961-1973) and estates (1959-1965).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
